awd_titl_txt: Support for student travel to international linguistics conference in Hong Kong
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide funding for graduate student conference travel to the 9th International Gender and Language Association (IGALA 9) conference. This is the first time that the conference will be held in China. Participating in the conference will afford the students an opportunity to share their work in an international forum and to impact the field as it develops in this region of the world. The award is consistent with NSF's mission of developing the next generation of scientists and promoting international scientific collaborations.
 
The IGALA 9 conference has taken as its theme, "Time and Transition." The conference will address such questions as: how discourse, gender, and language intersect with rapid change; how meanings are discursively constructed across various timescales; how short-term performances persist across time; and how self is projected discursively into the future while drawing on the past.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This award provided travel grants for 15 highly qualified students based at universities in the U.S. to present their research and gain professional experience at the 9th biennial conference of the International Gender and Language Association (IGALA 9), which was held May 19-21 at the City University of Hong Kong. The International Gender and Language Association (IGALA) is the major, international scholarly organization for researchers of language, gender, and sexuality; IGALA’s biennial conference is the primary scholarly venue for research in the field. Participation in the conference, therefore, was a valuable professional experience for graduate students conducting research in this area. There was an impressive, and impressively diverse, pool of over 25 graduate students eligible for the travel funding. Students were considered eligible for the funding if they had abstracts that were accepted for presentation at IGALA 9 and they were attending U.S. educational institutions, chiefly graduate programs in languages, linguistics and anthropology. 

The international conference experience at IGALA 9 not only exposed U.S.-based graduate students to international scholarship on language, gender, and sexuality, but it also allowed them to disseminate their own work to a broad, international audience. The 9th biennial meeting of the conference was the first time that IGALA had met in China, where, according to local organizers, research on language, gender, and sexuality is still in its infancy. By sharing their work at IGALA 9, U.S. graduate student scholars were able to have an impact on the shape of the field as it develops in this region of the world. At the same time, given that the conference was hosted in Hong Kong (China), one of the four so-called ’BRIC’ nations (Brazil, Russia, India, and China), the key emergent economies on the global stage, U.S. graduate student researchers were able to gain important and timely insights into the relationship between language, gender, and sexuality in this pivotal nation through their participation in IGALA 9. The conference also included several targeted opportunities for graduate student mentoring and professional development, including panel discussions on scholarly publishing and on the job search.


Last Modified: 05/18/2017
Modified by: Holly R Cashman
